ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the course is almost (if not already) at a 3-credit level.

So the only thing that I felt was missing was that in the beginning of the semester we were asked what aspects we would like to have a focus on, and despite international forest ops being requested by a couple of people, it never really came up.

Question 3 - many students in the class, including myself, agreed that it should be a 3 credit class. Between the homework assignments and field trips, I dedicated a lot of time to this class outside of the classroom.
This is listed as a 2 credit course. However, the workload was comparable to my 3 credit courses. This should certainly be considered a 3 credit course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Case studies and in class discussions.
I'd say the field trips. Learned so much there and I think it's a great concept to first send us to Spooner Hill to get the hang of it and later do our own harvest plan with our own landowners.
The field trips were a great aspect of the class, that really helped understand the concepts and ideas.
The professor encouraged a welcoming and engaging class atmosphere.
I enjoyed the semester long group project and the numerous opportunities to present in class. It was a great way to practice public speaking in a comfortable environment.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Guest speakers and field trips. I felt like there were too many field trips for a 2 credit course. Those of us taking silviculture really struggled with back to back field trips, or multiple field trips in a weekend. It was hard not to fall behind on work.
Sometimes it seemed a bit unorganized, but that might just have been my feeling. But generally it was hard to know the structure and topics of the course in the beginning.
The slide presentations early in the semester should be more clearly presented. The professor was often too quick moving through the material.
More time to discuss the readings. Towards the end of the semester it was difficult to figure out which readings were due when since we diverged from the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, it was effective.
The field trips were perfectly integrated into the course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is an excellent part of the MF curriculum, and provided us with a great foundation for understanding harvest operations. Wish that this class could sync up better with other forestry classes during the semester so we didn't have conflicting/back to back field trips.
An essential forestry skill is to know how forest operations work. This course give a good overview.
I am studying forestry - this class is essential.
This course is recommended for my degree program. I think it's highly valuable for every forester, even if you never plan on working operations it's important to understand the basics.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I felt it would be a good way to gather some basic knowledge of forest harvest operations and the day-to-day responsibilities of a forester.
I'm doing a Master of Forestry and this course teachers about an aspect of forestry that is not sufficiently covered in any other course.
Necessary for my degree program and future career.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely
Yes
Mostly. I think I would have liked to know a bit more on how to apply it in an international context when we don't have high tech machines available. And what we should have kept in mind then.

It gave me a very good introduction to forest management operations, I previously had no real understanding of how timber is harvested in the forestry industry. It will be very helpful for my summer internship and working going forward.
yes
Yes, I learned a great deal from this course which was supplemented by the Southern field tour and the field trip to Bavaria.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to dig into a case study. I struggled a little with getting everyone to meet/show up on time for group meetings, but everyone seems to have a different work schedule.

In the groupwork it was at times to me unclear what exactly we were supposed to research, which lead to us more or less researching everything. Also it wasn't clearly communicated when and in how many pieces the presentation of the gathered knowledge should go. I recommend that the teacher agrees with each group IN THE BEGINNING OF THE SEMESTER on deadlines for multiple presentations or A deadline for one big presentation. I like that Mike is trying to keep it flexible, but let's face it we are students and operate under deadlines. A class without a deadline is a class that will receive less attention.

For the semester-long project, it was good to be able to dive in deep to a specific issue regarding forest management operations. However, it would have been good to have more specific instruction on the timeline, deliverables, etc for the project as it felt somewhat unclear about when we were supposed to have what done.
Working in groups was a great way to connect with my classmates and accomplish much more than I could have done singly.

I recommend switching up the groups between the semester long case study and the harvest plan to give students the opportunity to work with others. I did enjoy the groups project because it gave us the opportunity to conduct in-depth research and make professional connections with a region/topic of our choosing.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it!
To take the Southern Forestry Field trip with it, without it I don't know how much I'd really have learned. Gives the field trip time I marked earlier as "insufficient" in the course alone.
If you're going to study forestry, you should absolutely take this course.
